metadata.name: Information Retrieval
metadata.description: Search and information retrieval capabilities including query formulation, search refinement, relevance judgment, and citation navigation. These concepts enable interpretability of how models find and retrieve information.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: The process of finding and extracting relevant information from repositories, databases, or collections in response to an information need

positive_examples: Information retrieval matched the query terms against the indexed document collection.
The IR system ranked results by relevance to the user's information need.
Effective information retrieval bridges the vocabulary gap between query and document.
Information retrieval involves both recall (finding all relevant items) and precision (avoiding irrelevant ones).
training_hints.disambiguation: Systematic retrieval process, not mere search execution

candidates.definition: Constructing effective search queries that express an information need in terms the retrieval system can process

positive_examples: Query formulation translated the conceptual question into specific search terms and operators.
Effective query formulation anticipated synonyms and variant terminology.
The query was formulated using Boolean operators to combine concepts appropriately.
Query formulation balanced specificity (precision) against breadth (recall).
training_hints.disambiguation: Strategic construction of effective queries, not mere term entry

candidates.definition: Identifying the most salient and discriminating terms from an information need or document for use in searching

positive_examples: Keyword extraction identified 'transformer architecture' and 'attention mechanism' as key search terms.
Extracting keywords from the abstract helped formulate the literature search strategy.
Keyword extraction distinguished high-value terms from common stopwords.
The system extracted keywords using TF-IDF to identify discriminating terms.
training_hints.disambiguation: Systematic identification of salient terms, not arbitrary word selection

candidates.definition: Iteratively improving search queries based on results, narrowing or broadening scope to better match the information need

positive_examples: Search refinement added date filters after the initial results included outdated sources.
Refining the search, the user added exclusion terms to filter out irrelevant meanings.
Search refinement used relevant results to discover additional keywords for expansion.
The refinement narrowed from 10,000 results to 50 highly relevant papers.
training_hints.disambiguation: Strategic query improvement based on result analysis

candidates.definition: Assessing whether retrieved items satisfy the information need, distinguishing relevant from irrelevant results

positive_examples: Relevance judgment determined that despite the keyword match, the paper addressed a different phenomenon.
Quick relevance judgment scanned titles and abstracts before examining full texts.
Relevance assessment distinguished marginally relevant background from directly pertinent sources.
The relevance judgment considered not just topical match but methodological appropriateness.
training_hints.disambiguation: Discriminating assessment of result utility, not mere review

candidates.definition: Moving through linked information structures using hyperlinks, cross-references, and relational connections

positive_examples: Source navigation followed the 'See also' links to discover related entries.
Navigating the source, the researcher found the supplementary materials with raw data.
Source navigation traced the breadcrumb hierarchy to understand the document's context.
Navigation through the linked sources revealed an entire subfield not captured by keyword search.

candidates.definition: Following references forward (who cited this?) and backward (what does this cite?) to discover related work

positive_examples: Citation chasing backward revealed the foundational papers that established the paradigm.
Forward citation tracking found recent papers building on the seminal 2010 study.
Citation chasing identified a highly-cited paper missed by keyword search.
Following citations revealed the intellectual lineage connecting disparate research threads.
training_hints.disambiguation: Strategic citation-based discovery, not mere reference checking

candidates.definition: Retrieval based on meaning and conceptual similarity rather than exact keyword matching

positive_examples: Semantic search found documents about 'automobile' when the query used 'car.'
The semantic search system understood that 'Python programming' differs from 'python snake.'
Semantic retrieval matched the query intent even when exact terms weren't present in documents.
Neural semantic search used embeddings to find conceptually similar passages.

candidates.definition: Retrieval using logical operators (AND, OR, NOT) to combine search terms precisely

positive_examples: Boolean search: (climate change OR global warming) AND (policy OR legislation) NOT opinion.
The Boolean query used parentheses to group terms and control operator precedence.
Boolean search provided precise control but required expertise to use effectively.
Using Boolean NOT excluded irrelevant homonyms from the result set.
training_hints.disambiguation: Precise logical query construction, not mere operator use

candidates.definition: Filtering search results by multiple independent dimensions or attributes such as date, type, author, or topic

positive_examples: Faceted search filtered by publication year, document type, and subject heading simultaneously.
Using faceted navigation, the researcher narrowed results to peer-reviewed articles from 2020-2024.
Faceted search revealed that 80% of results were conference papers rather than journal articles.
The facet counts showed distribution of results across different categories.
